author: William Baldwin
title: Best ETFs: Large-cap Funds
text:
This group includes the $177 billion granddaddy of exchange-traded funds, the SPDR S&P 500 ( SPY ), other funds that own the S&P 500 and funds that own the whole U.S. stock market.The best bargains are found among the broad market funds. Vanguard Total Stock Market ( VTI ), which holds 3,800 stocks, comes in with a $46 cost per $10,000 invested over a decade. Right behind at $50 is the Schwab U.S. Broad Market ( SCHB ), with 2,500 stocks.Why is SPY so far down the list? Two reasons. One is its expense ratio. Its early days this State Street product was quite the bargain, but nowadays 9 basis points ($9 per $10,000 annually) is no longer competitive. The other reason is that this fund does not lend out securities to short-sellers, a source of income that offsets costs in many funds, especially those holding smaller companies outside the S&P 500.The cheap index fund is Wall Street’s gift to investors. Its enhanced index funds are a way of taking something back. Take a look at the bottom portion of our table, showing funds with special weights. Instead of a capitalization weighting they lean to dividends or growth or value or other factors. You pay extra for these enhancements. Price tags run twice as high on average.Do special weights enhance your returns? In hindsight they sure do. If you could turn back the clock 20 years you could soundly beat a simple cap-weighted portfolio by selecting just the right factor. But now, with a giant “smart beta” crowd chasing the same factors? The only thing that is sure to be enhanced is the revenue going to fund vendors.If you must buy a specially weighted ETF, get one of the more affordable ones. Among portfolios weighted to growth companies, Vanguard Growth ( VUG ) is the largest and very easy to trade, but long-term holders would be better off in iShares Core U.S. Growth ( IUSG ) or Schwab U.S. Large-Cap Growth ( SCHG ).Among funds aimed at the dividend thirsty, Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ( VIG ) is the big seller but the Schwab U.S. Dividend Equity ( SCHD ) is a better long-term buy.Rules for the Best ETFs scorecard, and links to 13 categories of funds, can be found here .
